metadata.title: Pattern of Vascular Disease in Lombardia (Italy) during the first month of the COVID-19 outbreak

body_text.text: The first confirmed case of COVID-19 infection in Italy was reported in Lombardia region on February 20, 2020, following the outbreak in Hubei Province in China, where in just 30 days it spread from the city of Wuhan to the entire country (1). Aggressive policies allowed containment of the epidemic in China, however by that time the WHO had declared a global pandemic.

The first cases in Italy were detected in a few small urban centers of Lombardia and the Veneto regions and in spite of the immediate quarantine, the infection rapidly spread to other regions in Italy. Still the largest number of COVID-19 cases were recorded in Lombardia, were the epidemic has been particularly virulent and highly lethal. Lombardia has a high number of elderly citizens, according to the 2019 report of the Italian Institute of Statistics (ISTAT) 13.7% of the citizens are over 65 years of age and that for each 100 inhabitants < 14 years old there are 165,5 who are above age 65; a very high index of an aging population. Life expectancy in Lombardia before the pandemic was 84 years , 3 years above the European life expectancy.

As the virulence and lethality of the COVID-19 epidemic in Italy was unusually grave, both the central and local authorities rapidly initiated measures of social distancing and on March 22, 2020 a lockdown was ordered for the entire country with only essential services still functioning. These measures are still active as of April 15, 2020 when the number of new cases has reached a plateau. These measures initially received skeptical comments from most of the other countries, however in a matter of weeks most western countries followed in issuing similar drastic measures. From an epidemiological point of view, many of these countries are reporting a similar pattern of infection curves with 2-3 weeks delay over Italy.

The public health system of Lombardia, where publicly run and privately-run hospitals coexist, has been struck very hard by the epidemic, especially in municipalities like Cremona Lodi and Bergamo where the hospitals were rapidly overwhelmed. The regional healthcare authorities decided to create e Hub/Spoke system for cardiovascular and surgical emergencies, where a small number of large centers (Hubs: IRCCS Ospedale San Raffaele Milano, Fondazione Poliambulanza Brescia, Centro Cardiologico Monzino Milano, ASST Milanese Ospedale di Legnano) would serve the whole region for non–elective cases, while greatly limiting the number of elective ones. [At these centers the emergency admission of patients with respiratory (influenza – like) and non-respiratory symptoms are physically separated and follow different pathways (i.e. dedicated wards, elevators, radiology units etc.] This allowed most other hospitals (Spokes) to concentrate their resources for COVID-19 related cases. Moreover, a significant number of dedicated ICU beds have been made available in a matter of days at both publicly and privately-run centers. Clearly many further logistics adjustments had to be made in order to optimize the resources to this rapidly changing situation, moreover medical teaching also underwent radical changes.

Being one of the 4 Hubs selected by the local health authorities of Lombardia for vascular surgical emergencies, our Institution is cooperating with 8 Spokes serving a population of approximately 2.5M inhabitants. Several interesting patterns have emerged: during the initial days, in fact, the number of non-elective admissions of subjects with vascular disease was lower than usual, possibly due to a reluctance in the general population to seek assistance in a hospital where they believed they could be in contact with COVID-19 patients.

As we entered the second week, the number of vascular emergencies resumed, and there was a clear increase in acute peripheral arterial occlusive disease; the tendency was towards older patients (median age 75 years, range 50-96), with advanced ischemia and below knee thrombosis. [Table I
] This is unusual for us and clearly different from our customary patient mix.

As of the third week a significant number of cases initially hospitalized for COVID-19 related pneumonia, both on and off artificial ventilators presented with peripheral ischemia of both lower and occasionally upper limbs and required treatment. Interestingly, most of these patients were already receiving antithrombotic prophylaxis. During Duplex ultrasonographic assessment of these patients the deep venous circulation was also studied showing an alarmingly high number of deep venous thrombosis (DVT), with little or no additional specific symptoms. We therefore screened for DVT 108 Covid-19 patients, the incidence was 23% for patients on ventilators and 8% for patients off ventilators; particularly affected were the popliteal and calf veins.

Recent evidence on anomalous coagulation features in patients with severe COVID-19 related pneumonia might explain a higher incidence of arterial and venous thrombosis and suggested heparin prophylaxis in this subgroup of patients. (2) Given the number of observed arterial and venous thrombosis cases, research studies are being set up to understand mechanisms underlying COVID-19 associated hypercoagulability and possible virus-mediated endothelial dysfunction. Other research lines are currently running, aimed to investigate COVID-19 patients’ response to different anticoagulants, and to identify blood-circulating biomarkers as predictors of thrombotic complications.

We are now well into our 5th week of the COVID-19 emergency and we are dealing with the new challenges in an increasingly efficient way. The supply chain poses some issues not only for personal protective equipment (PPE) but also for seemingly trivial devices such as thrombectomy catheters, peripheral vascular grafts, specific drugs etc. Centers that are treating vascular patients in the times of the COVID-19 pandemic could face similar issues and could be better prepared.

Lastly, adequate protection and wise allocation of the human resources, including nurses, doctors, assisting personnel is of paramount importance since the infection have not spared healthcare workers. In Italy 116 physicians died from COVID-19 related disease since March 10, 2020.
